choq- ± `en` @seaqtaq #dzaaHAM5Y

⚠ Choq jí baq daqkea ra baq daqdekı da. -1 `en` @oldexamples #FeyVPNiW9lGl

quantifier: ‘the/these’; quantifier: ke X refers to specific thing(s) that are X, among all X that are in the UoD.

⚠ ke -1 `en` @oldofficial #ihs2JwjqgDW
determiner: ‘the’; definite quantifier

ké +1 `en` @official #2EG1It1W3Jf
determiner: ‘EXO’; exophoric; this X (not previously mentioned)

ke- +1 `en` @official #G2biwGim1
determiner prefix form: ‘of:EXO’; fills object of verb with ké (exophoric; this X (not previously mentioned))

The proposition "what satisfies the property ▯" satisfies the property ▯. In other words: considering the two properties ▯ and ▯, for all X, the proposition that X satisfies the first property is true iff it satisfies the second property, and furthermore, the proposition that X does not satisfy the first property is false iff it doesn't satisfy the second property.

näꝡa ± `en` @Ilmen #Exo8377ZD
particle: discourse-level frame-setting cleft — placed after a tense or modal expression, setting it as the domain in which the following sentences are evaluated as true, until the next occurrence of ⟪näꝡa⟫. May be used for introducing storytelling, in which case the following sentences are set to describe a context unrelated to the “here and now” of the speaker and addressees, describing instead events set in the past or in an imaginary universe.

teoqdue -2 `en` @xylochoron #O_ZFg72t3
▯ is the answer to ▯, where the second blank necessarily refers to whatever question you just asked me."tẻoqdūe" is a technically logical answer to any question whatsoever. questioner: "Why do you beat your dog?" Answerer who doesn't feel like explaining that they never did beat their dog so the question is irrelevant and answers: "tẻoqdūe." Technically this counts, by definition, as an answer to the questioner's question, and may signal the answerer does not feel the need to give a more detailed answer. "Why are you such a dork?" "tẻoqdūe."

Tuqca -2 `en` @xylochoron #7_WIe-Vr0
▯ is the ultimate explanation for everything in set ▯. (Defaults to the ultimate cause of the universe in context.) "Why didn't you do the laundry?" "Tủqcā" (could be translated as "The physical laws plus boundary conditions of the universe." "Tủqcā" is technically an answer to pretty much any question, and a signal that perhaps you should specify what level of explanation you are looking for before asking, like "what did you do this morning instead of the laundry" instead. Can also probably be used in physics contexts.
